questions.text: Which of the following parasites is ovoviviparous?
questions.solution:
Strongyloides stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite.

Nematodes are classified as follows:

  • Oviparous - lay eggs:
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria
    • Segmented eggs:  Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis
  • Viviparous - produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi
  • Ovoviviparous – lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., Strongyloides stercoralis

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

The larvae molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

The rhabditiform larva can be seen on microscopic examination of stool.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode
Diphyllobothrium latum Plerocercoid larva Eggs or segments of the tapeworm
Taenia saginata Cysticercus bovis Egg
Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestinal taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg Protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
Trematode
Schistosoma spp. Cercariae Nonoperculated Eggs
Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode
Ascaris lumbricoides Egg Unembryonated eggs in stool

Ancylostoma duodenale

Necator americanus

 Filariform larva Eggs (in fresh stool), larva ( in old stool )
Strongyloides stercoralis Filariform larva Rhabditiform larva
Trichuris trichuria Embryonated Egg Unembryonated Egg
Enterobius vermicularis Egg Eggs from perianal skin
Filarial nematodes Third stage Filarial larva (L3) Microfilariae
Trichinella spiralis First stage larva (L1) Trichinella antibody test
Dracunculus medinensis Third stage filariform larva (L3) Adult worm
Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presented with complaints of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 1 week.  The stool microscopy revealed the following.  What is the appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy showing the rhabditiform larva of S. stercoralis are suggestive of strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition would be ivermectin.

Strongyloidiasis is caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of perianal itching which is worse in the night.  The scotch tape method demonstrates eggs as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perianal itching and the scotch tape microscopy showing the eggs are suggestive of infestation with pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis).

The eggs of pinworm are plano-convex in shape, colorless, non-bile stained, and float in the saturated salt solution. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and the scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod, at one end of which a piece of transparent cellophane is attached with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. It is returned to the test tube and sent to the laboratory. The cellophane piece is detached, spread over a glass side, and examined microscopically.

The image given below shows the NIH swab.

 

In scotch tape method, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with sticky side down. Then a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

 

The below image shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by​ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A college student came to the OPD with fever and muscle aches. He tells you he had consumed smoked pork at a party 2 weeks back. Following this, he had developed abdominal cramps and diarrhea which had resolved on their own. CBC revealed eosinophilia and the muscle biopsy showed the following finding. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and muscle biopsy showing larvae are suggestive of trichinellosis. It is caused by Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever and myalgia.

These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy.

 Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are:

  • T. solium
  • T. cruzi (amastigote)

 The image below shows Trichinella spiralis larvae within the muscle.

questions.text: In a patient with a positive  Bachman intradermal test, which of the following infections will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Bachman intradermal test is used for the diagnosis of trichinellosis.

In this test, 1:5,000 or 1:10,000 dilution of the trichinella larval antigen is injected intradermally. An erythematous wheal appears in positive cases within 15-20 minutes. The test remains positive for years after infection.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

Skin test

Diagnosis

Casoni’s test

Hydatid disease

Montenegro test/Leishmanin test

Kala-azar

Frenkel’s test

Toxoplasmosis

Fairley’s test

Schistosomiasis

Bachman test

Trichinellosis

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). It is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide.

Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum). The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior.

Man is the natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containing eggs of ascaris. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.

Related Pearl: Commonly known names of some important parasites

a. Trematodes

Parasite

Paragonimus westermani

Oriental lung fluke

Fasciolopsis buski

Giant intestinal fluke

Fasciola hepatica

Sheep liver fluke

Clonorchis sinensis

Chinese liver fluke/oriental liver fluke

Schistosoma japonicum

Oriental blood fluke

 b. Cestodes

Parasite

Common name

Taenia saginata

Beef tapeworm

Diphyllobothrium latum

Fish tapeworm

Taenia solium

Pork tapeworm

Hymenolepis nana

Dwarf tapeworm

Hymenolepis diminuta

Rat tapeworm

Dipylidium caninum

Double-pored dog tapeworm

 c. Nematodes:

Parasite

Common name

Ascaris lumbricoides

Common roundworm

Ancylostoma duodenale

Old world hookworm

Necator americanus

American or new world hookworm

Trichuris trichiura

Whipworm

Thread or pinworm

Dracunculus medinensis

Guinea worm

Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs

questions.text: A 9- year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever and colicky abdominal pain. An erect X-ray abdomen showed multiple air-fluid levels. Stool examination revealed the following egg. Which of the following is false about the organism causing this condition?

choices.text: Egg containing L1 larva is infective

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of ascariasis caused by Ascaris lumbricoides. Embryonated egg containing the L3 larva is the infective form.

Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host. The infection is acquired via the consumption of food or water contaminated with eggs. The eggs hatch after reaching the duodenum to release the larvae. These penetrate the intestinal mucosa and enter the portal vessels. From the liver, larvae reach the systemic circulation, lungs and then reach the small intestine to produce symptoms.

Clinical features:

Due to the migrating larvae:

  • Fever
  • Dry cough
  • Asthmatic wheezing
  • Loeffler's syndrome

Due to the adult worm:

  • Asymptomatic
  • Nutritional effects - protein-energy malnutrition, Vitamin A deficiency
  • Toxic effects - urticaria, angioedema due to hypersensitivity
  • Mechanical effects - colicky abdominal pain, volvulus, and intestinal obstruction
  • Ectopic ascariasis - acute biliary obstruction, pancreatitis, and obstructive appendicitis.

The life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides is given below.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestinal taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg Protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
Trematode

Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode

Ancylostoma duodenale

Necator americanus

 Filariform larva Eggs (in fresh stool), larva ( in old stool )

questions.text: What is the most common cause for visceral larva migrans?
questions.solution:
The most common cause for visceral larva migrans is Toxocara canis. It occurs most commonly in children and presents as fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pneumonitis.

Larva migrans is generally seen when human infection occurs with nonhuman species of nematodes. It can be classified into cutaneous or visceral types, depending on whether the larval migration takes place in the skin or in deeper tissues.

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae that are acquired via the oral route. Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae (most commonly Ancylostoma braziliense) that are acquired via skin penetration.

Patients having visceral larva migrans may develop neurological disturbances (neural larva migrans) and endophthalmitis (ophthalmic larva migrans).

Differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans:

  Cutaneous larva migrans Visceral larva migrans
Tissue involved Skin Various organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyes
Infecting Organism Mostly by non-human nematodes Mostly by non-human nematodes (mainly by dog and cat)
Portal of Entry Penetration of skin Ingestion of infected eggs
Eosinophilia Mild Persistent high
Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed
Treatment Thiabendazole Diethylcarbamazine and prednisolone

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness for the past 3 months. She is diagnosed to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals the following. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg is suggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale.

Eggs of both Ancylostoma duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

The hookworm eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and eggshell. Eggs float in the saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneous tissue. The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss.

The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale and 0.03 mL with Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with dry cough, low-grade fever and wheezing. He is diagnosed with  Loeffler’s syndrome.  Which of the following parasites does not cause this?
questions.solution:
Loeffler's syndrome is an eosinophilic inflammation of the lung caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis and Necator americanus. Enterobius vermicularis does not cause Loeffler’s syndrome.

It is associated with pneumonia characterized by dry cough, low-grade fever, wheezing, urticaria, and eosinophilia.

Parasites causing Loeffler’s syndrome are:

  • Migrating larva of:
    • Ascaris lumbricoides
    • Strongyloides stercoralis
    • Ancylostoma duodenale
    • Necator americanus
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Eggs of Paragonimus westermani
  • Entamoeba histolytica
  • Trichomonas tenax

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman had gone on a trek in the Amazon rainforest. A month later she presented to the OPD with the following lesion which was painful and pruritic. Her systemic examination was normal. Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing serpiginous skin lesions are suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption or ground itch. This is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they are unable to penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin.

It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry and serpiginous tracks in the epidermis. The symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneous lesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily. 

Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features.

The treatment includes:

  • Thiabendazole topical application
  • Albendazole 400mg/day X 3 days or
  • Ivermectin 200mcg/kg single dose stat

The differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are:

  Cutaneous larva migrans Visceral larva migrans
Tissue involved Skin Various organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyes
Infecting Organism Mostly by non-human nematodes Mostly by non-human nematodes (mainly by dog and cat)
Portal of Entry Penetration of skin Ingestion of infected eggs
Eosinophilia Mild Persistent high
Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed
Treatment Thiabendazole Diethylcarbamazine and prednisolone

Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larva currens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesion in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised, hyper-infestation syndrome occurs with paralytic ileus and secondary Gram-negative sepsis.

questions.text: Which the following filarial worms are non-pathogenic to humans?
questions.solution:
Mansonella ozzardi is generally non-pathogenic to humans. 

Option A: Onchocerca volvulus infection may manifest as skin nodules or onchocercoma which are formed as a result of fibroblastic reaction around adult worms deep in the subcutaneous tissues. Microfilariae cause lesions in the skin and eyes.

Options B and C: In lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria and Brugia), the typical manifestations are caused by the adult worms blocking lymph nodes and vessels. Microfilaria (larval form) are responsible for allergic manifestations seen in occult filariasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man  came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of his legs. On examination, you note bilateral non-pitting edema of the lower limbs with thickening of the overlying skin. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). The best next step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi.

Elephantiasis is a delayed sequel to repeated lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema. Repeated leakage of lymph into tissues first results in lymphedema, then to elephantiasis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

Option A: PCR is negative in chronic filariasis.

Options B & D: Lymphangiography and lymphoscintigraphy may be used to demonstrate abnormal lymphatic urinary fistula leading to chyluria in chronic filariasis.

questions.text: A child from Bihar is brought to the AIIMS ER with a high-grade fever. On examination, bilaterally enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes are present. The peripheral smear examination finding is shown in the image. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of infection with Brugia malayi.

Acute infection may manifest as acute adenolymphangitis which is characterized by high fever, lymphatic inflammation (lymphangitis and lymphadenitis) and transient local edema. The most commonly affected lymph nodes are inguinal nodes followed by axillary nodes which become enlarged, painful and tender.

The following are the characteristic features of microfilaria of Brugia malayi:

  • Smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti.
  • Shows kinks and secondary curves.
  • Cephalic space is longer.
  • Carries double stylets at the anterior end.
  • Nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films.
  • Tail tip carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: A patient from Kerala has presented to your OPD with fever. A magnified view of peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the organism seen?

choices.text: DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day
Second stage filariform larva is the infective form
Microfilaria is the major diagnostic form
Filarial stage of adult worms are responsible for disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. The third stage filariform larva is the infective form.

Wuchereria bancrofti infection is usually asymptomatic. The symptoms are due to obstruction of lymphatics by the filarial stage of adult worms.

The lymphatic vessels of the male genitalia are most commonly affected in bancroftian filariasis, producing episodic funiculitis, epididymitis, and orchitis. Adenolymphangitis of the extremities is less common. 

Hydrocele is the most common sign of chronic bancroftian filariasis, followed by lymphedema, elephantiasis, and chyluria. The swelling involves the whole leg, the whole arm, the scrotum, the vulva, or the breast.

DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day.

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Assam presented with the finding shown in the image.  He had also developed a painless swelling in his elbow 2 years back which has gradually been increasing in size.  Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing sclerosing keratitis are suggestive of onchocerchiasis (river blindness). The drug of choice is ivermectin. 

It is caused by Onchocerca volvulus. It is also known as convoluted filaria or blinding filaria.

The vector is blackfly (Simulium species) which breed in fast-flowing rivers, and therefore the disease is most common along the course of rivers. Hence, it is also called river blindness.

The usual presentation is formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes.

The microfilaria in the eyes cause photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestation is sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which causes blindness. It is the 2nd major infective cause of blindness in the world after trachoma.

Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were used earlier but are not used nowadays. DEC destroys microfilariae but usually causes Mazzotti reaction consisting of pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, hypotension, and occasionally, eye damage.

Note: Onchocerciasis is not endemic in India but sporadic cases have been reported from North-Eastern India.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to your clinic with photosensitivity, redness, and watering of the eyes for the last 2 days. She shows you this photo of a swelling in her hand that had arisen 2 weeks back but disappeared in just 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing Calabar swelling is suggestive of loiasis caused by Loa loa.

Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation that appear as Loa loa wanders through the subcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere.

Loa loa is transmitted by the bite of Chrysops species (deerflies). The infective form is the third stage microfilaria. After entry into human skin, it grows into an adult worm.

The ocular manifestations occur when the worm reaches the subconjunctival tissue during its wanderings. They include:

  • Granuloma in bulbar conjunctiva
  • Painless edema of the eyelids
  • Proptosis.

The image below shows Calabar swelling.

The image below shows a live, adult Loa loa in the anterior chamber of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as Weingarten syndrome?
questions.solution:
Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is also known as Weingarten syndrome.

Tropical eosinophilia occurs as a result of hypersensitivity reaction to microfilarial antigens and not directly due to lymphatic involvement. It is a manifestation of occult filariasis (Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome).

Clinical features of occult filariasis include massive eosinophilia and hepatosplenomegaly.

Synonyms of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia include - 

  • Weingarten syndrome
  • Pseudo-tuberculosis of the lung
  • Eosinophilic pseudo-leukemia
  • Tropical eosinophilic asthma
  • Frimodt-Moller and Barton's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is known as serpent worm?
questions.solution:
Dracunculus medinensis is known as serpent worm.

It is a viviparous nematode.

This has been eradicated from India and all of the southeast Asian region in the year 2000.

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective hosts:
A. Diphyllobothrium 1. Sheep
B. Paragonimus 2. Crayfish
C. Brugia 3. Cyclops
D. Fasciola 4. Mansonia
questions.solution:
Parasite Definitive host First intermediate host Second intermediate host
Diphyllobothrium Humans Cyclops Cyclops and fish
Paragonimus Humans Snail Crayfish and crab
Fasciola Sheep and humans Snail Aquatic vegetations
Brugia  Humans Mansonia mosquito  -
